results.title: The Silenced
results.credit_line:
Julie Gough
Single-channel video work
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
results.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough
description_for_label:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough

results.title: Webwurld
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson and Simon Ward

Single-channel video work

ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Soundtrack by Andrew Clarke. video, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Webwurld appears like fragments of a dream, mesmerising its viewers with a cosmic, otherworldly dimension that seems to stretch out in every direction.

constellations_primary.name: Webwurlds
constellations_primary.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
Webwurld appears like fragments of a dream, mesmerising its viewers with a cosmic, otherworldly dimension that seems to stretch out in every direction. Working from Jess Johnson’s complex hand-drawn images, video artist Simon Ward rebirths her 2D images as chimerical 3D animations.

“My drawings are meshworks of cultural symbology, humanoid clones, messianic figures and alien runes placed in architectural settings. This practice feeds into installations and collaborations in animation, music, fashion, virtual reality and textile art. These additional mediums bring the world of my drawings into physical and virtual spaces, providing an immersive experience for audiences.” - Jess Johnson
description_for_label:

results.title: Darling Darling
results.credit_line:
Gabriella Hirst

Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound, 25:30

SanDisk Memory Card, gold leaf, in collaboration with Barbara Dabrowa, AGNSW Senior Conservator of Fine Arts – Frames

Courtesy the artist
results.material_description: Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound and gilded SD card
results.brief_description:
Darling Darling presents two contrasting but linked responses to the idea of conservation. One side of the screen shows the meticulous care taken to restore WC Piguenit’s prized 1895 painting of the Barka-Darling River, The flood in the Darling, 1890, while the other side reveals the present-day neglect of the river itself. Excess upstream water diversion and climate change have contributed to severe water scarcity and mass fish kills in recent years.

In composing her shots of the river, Hirst references Australia’s beloved landscape painting tradition, and colonial-era artists like Eugene von Guérard, John Glover, Conrad Martens, Nicholas Chevalier, Ludwig Becker and of course, WC Piguenit. While their romantic paintings capture a sense of nature as awe inspiring, they also served the more material purpose of framing resources to be owned and exploited by European settlers, a visual expression of the concept of terra nullius.

Darling Darling invites us to question the role played by Western visual art traditions in shaping the value systems that allow such an extreme environmental crisis to unfold right before our eyes.

Gabriella Hirst (she/her) is an artist. She was born and grew up on Cammeraygal land (Australia) and is currently living between Berlin and London. She works primarily with moving image, performance, and with the garden as a site of critique and care. Gabriella’s practice and research explores connections between various manifestations of capture and control – spanning plant taxonomies, landscape painting, art conservation and nuclear history.

results.title: CATARACT (concrete)
results.credit_line:
Daniel von Sturmer. Aotearoa New Zealand

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop

Commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video
results.brief_description: Everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality.

constellations_primary.name: Now watch this
constellations_primary.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.headline_credit_for_label:
Australia, 2020

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop.
results.description:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.
description_for_label:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.

results.title: More Winners [Series]
results.brief_description: A second series of highly acclaimed television programs for children. ‘Winners’ and ‘More Winners’ are anthology series of fourteen telemovies, featuring historical drama, comedy, science fiction, fantasy, adventure and social realism. Each film celebrates individuality and the facing of difficult situations with courage and ingenuity.

Each film celebrates individuality and the facing of difficult situations with courage and ingenuity.

results.title: More Winners : The Journey
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Australian Children's Television Foundation and Richard Mason
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
Justus Zukermann, a wealthy prospector, lives with his 12 year old daughter, Ada on a windswept mountain plateau. Since Ada’s mother died, Martha and her step-daughter, Agnes, have been employed to run the household. One day Justus is fatally injured in a fall. Before he dies he orders Ada to journey south to find her true inheritance. Agnes is to accompany her. Martha (who is in fact a witch) has for years envied Justus’ wealth. She determines to secure the hidden fortune for herself and orders Agnes to kill Ada and steal the map once they reach the forest. Agnes is unable to kill Ada and the two girls are drawn together. After several adventures the girls find a secret cave, unearth the buried treasure and a letter from Justus, which makes the purpose of their journey very clear. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jane Oehr, Australian Children’s Television Foundation and Richard Mason

results.title: More Winners : The Journey (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Richard Mason and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
Twelve year old Ada lives with her father on top of a mountain, looked after by Martha, the housekeeper, and Martha’s daughter Agnes. On his death- bed, Ada’s father tells her to journey south to seek her true inheritance. But Martha, who is a witch, is determined to get the inheritance first. She orders Agnes to follow Ada, kill her and steal her map. But Agnes is unable to kill her friend and the two are drawn together on a journey for buried treasure.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jane Oehr, Richard Mason and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: More Winners : The Big Wish
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
In the Enchanted Realm the Faeries are in trouble. According to the Charters of the Grand Masters, they must give away seven wishes to the humans every 100 years or they will lose their magic powers. The last wish was given away 99 years and 364 days before. Prince Wilton is sent to earth to dispose of the 7 wishes to a sceptical and disbelieving human and before sundown. The only human being who will believe in him and make any wish is Christopher Walter Pratt (C W). C W doesn’t realise, however, that the last wish lasts forever. The lessons C W has taught and learnt leave their mark on him and those he meets on his journey through a truly magical day.

Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.

The lessons C W has taught and learnt leave their mark on him and those he meets on his journey through a truly magical day.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
In the Enchanted Realm the fairies are in trouble. According to the Charter of the Grand Master, they must give away seven wishes to the humans every 100 years or lose their magic powers. But the only human who will believe in them is Christopher Walter Pratt (C.W.). C.W. has one day to enjoy his seven wishes - what he doesn’t know is that the last wish lasts forever.
